dt: {bc}a circumstance or action that offends propriety or established moral conceptions or disgraces those associated with it
{bc}a person whose conduct offends propriety or morality
{bc}loss of or damage to reputation caused by actual or apparent violation of morality or propriety {bc}{sx|disgrace||}
{bc}indignation, chagrin, or bewilderment brought about by a flagrant violation of morality, propriety, or religious opinion
{bc}discredit brought upon religion by unseemly conduct in a religious person
{bc}conduct that causes or encourages a lapse of faith or of religious obedience in another

pt: {sc}offense{/sc} {sc}sin{/sc} {sc}vice{/sc} {sc}crime{/sc} {sc}scandal{/sc} mean a transgression of law. {sc}offense{/sc} applies to the infraction of any law, rule, or code.

pt.t: at that school no {it}offense{/it} went unpunished

pt: {sc}sin{/sc} implies an offense against moral or religious law.
{sc}vice{/sc} applies to a habit or practice that degrades or corrupts.
{sc}crime{/sc} implies a serious offense punishable by the law of the state.
{sc}scandal{/sc} applies to an offense that outrages the public conscience.

pt.t: a career ruined by a sex {it}scandal{/it}

et: Middle English, from Late Latin {it}scandalum{/it} stumbling block, offense, from Greek {it}skandalon{/it} trap, stumbling block, offense; akin to Latin {it}scandere{/it} to climb
shortdef: a circumstance or action that offends propriety or established moral conceptions or disgraces those associated with it
a person whose conduct offends propriety or morality
loss of or damage to reputation caused by actual or apparent violation of morality or propriety : disgrace
